overview.short: Helicobacter species are Gram-negative, curved/spiral bacteria that are microaerophilic and commonly inhabit mucosal surfaces, especially the gastrointestinal tract.
overview.clinical_context: Clinically most significant for gastritis and peptic ulcer disease (H. pylori), but other species can be associated with enteritis or bacteremia in select settings.

field_notes.Oxygen Requirement: Helicobacter are typically microaerophilic (reduced O2 with added CO2).
field_notes.Urease: Urease varies by species; strong positivity is a hallmark for H. pylori.
field_notes.Sugar Fermentation: Generally asaccharolytic; carbohydrate fermentation is not expected.

key_differentiators.notes: Overlaps with Campylobacter; interpretation should incorporate urease and clinical context.
Urease positivity strongly supports Helicobacter over Campylobacter.

common_confusions.reason: Both can appear as curved/spiral Gram-negative organisms and prefer microaerophilic conditions.

when_to_question_identification: Strong carbohydrate fermentation profile is inconsistent with Helicobacter.
Strict aerobiosis (full O2) is inconsistent with Helicobacter growth.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Strong discriminator for H. pylori and helpful genus-level confirmation.
Confirms growth requirements consistent with Helicobacter.
Species-level ID when culture is available.
